newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's crude oil imports down 4.4% in Sept - MITI.
newsitem.headline: Japan's crude oil imports down 4.4% in Sept - MITI.

text.p: Japan's crude oil imports amounted to 20.27 million kilolitres in September, down 4.4 percent from the same month last year, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (MITI) said on Friday.
Crude imports have fallen from most areas, with the exception of China and Africa.
A MITI official attributed the decline in imports largely to loading schedules of crude oil shipments.
He added that crude oil imports for the July-September period were about the same as a year earlier, and had declined only 0.5 percent from the third quarter last year.
Japan imported a total of 124.07 million kl of crude oil in the first half of fiscal 1996/97, down 1.8 percent from April to September 1995.
The Middle East has traditionally been the largest source of crude oil for Japan, and in September the Gulf accounted for 78.8 percent of Japan's total oil imports.
The United Arab Emirates was the largest source of crude oil followed by Saudi Arabia and Iran.
Japan imported 5.18 million kl of crude oil from the United Arab Emirates, 3.37 million kl from Saudi Arabia and 2.56 million kl from Iran.
Crude oil from Africa showed a marked jump in September.
Japan imported a total of about 238,000 kl of oil from Africa in September, up 43.2 percent from August.
A total of 82,000 kl of Nigeria's Bonny Light crude was shipped to Japan in September, up 27.7 percent from August.
Japan also imported a total of 156,000 kl of Palanca crude from Angola. The crude was not imported in August.
China was another country that shipped more oil to Japan in September than in August.
Crude oil from China amounted to 1.45 million kl in September, up 15.7 percent from August.
Crude throughput in September amounted to 19.43 million kl, down 0.3 percent from a year earlier.
It was the first time in five months that crude throughput had shown a year-on-year decline.
